Content_wSideColumn.BodyCopy:
Idaho Falls, Idaho

Population: 53,279

Metro Area Population: 119,396

On average, there are 201 sunny days per year in Idaho Falls. The July high is around 87 degrees and in January, the low is 13. It is the largest metropolitan area of the Eastern Idaho region. The city is served by the Idaho Falls Regional Airport and is home to the Idaho Falls Chukars minor league baseball team.

 

Trends of Employment

The community's economy was mostly agriculturally focused until the Atomic Energy Commission opened the National Reactor Testing Station in the nearby desert in 1949. The town subsequently became largely dependent on high-income jobs from "The Site," officially called the Idaho National Laboratory (INL) since 2005. Since then the town has added call centers, a growing retail, entertainment, and restaurant sector, a regional medical center, and added funding for small businesses. Idaho Falls is becoming a regional business hub. It is also the home to several small to medium sized national corporations such as Melaleuca, Inc and Press-A-Print International.

Cost of Living

Compared to the rest of the country, Idaho Falls cost of living is 13.84% Lower than the U.S. average. The Idaho Falls Metro Area's cost of living is 12.41% lower than the U.S. average.

Based on Sperling's BestPlaces, the income per capita is $21,978, which includes all adults and children. The median household income is $45,899. The Metro Area per capita is $20,607, while the median household income is $46,849.

Transportation

The average one-way commute in Idaho Falls, ID takes 21 minutes. 79% of commuters drive their own car alone, 10% carpool with others, 6% take mass transit, and 4% work from home.
